Got it üëç ‚Äî you‚Äôre asking how to stop/kill Cisco AnyConnect processes like NAM (Network Access Manager) or the background service vpnagent.exe that runs when AnyConnect is installed.

Here‚Äôs a breakdown:

1. Understanding the processes

  • vpnagent.exe ‚Üí The ‚ÄúCisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Agent‚Äù background service. It runs at startup and manages VPN connections and related modules (including NAM if installed).
  • NAM service ‚Üí Installed as Cisco Network Access Manager; it replaces Windows‚Äô built-in network manager and automatically runs at system startup if enabled.

2. Stopping / killing AnyConnect processes (Windows)

Option A: Stop service properly

  1. Press Win+R, type services.msc, hit Enter.
  2. Look for:
    • Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Agent
    • Cisco Network Access Manager (if installed)
  3. Right-click ‚Üí Stop.
  4. To prevent auto-start: right-click ‚Üí Properties ‚Üí Set Startup type to Disabled (or Manual).

Option B: Task Manager kill

  1. Press Ctrl+Shift+Esc to open Task Manager.
  2. Find vpnagent.exe or any Cisco AnyConnect process.
  3. Right-click ‚Üí End task.
    (This only lasts until reboot or if the service relaunches automatically.)

3. Uninstalling modules you don‚Äôt want

If you only want VPN and not NAM:

  1. Go to Control Panel ‚Üí Programs and Features.
  2. Find Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client.
  3. Click Change ‚Üí Modify installation.
  4. Uncheck Network Access Manager (keep VPN enabled if you still need it).
  5. Finish ‚Äî this surgically removes NAM but leaves the VPN working.

‚ö†Ô∏è Notes / Cautions

  • Killing vpnagent.exe directly will also kill AnyConnect VPN functionality until you restart it.
  • If NAM is managing Wi-Fi/ethernet, killing it without reverting to the Windows network manager may drop your network connection.
  • Best practice is to disable/uninstall NAM if you don‚Äôt need it, rather than just force-killing.
